articles.headline: In a Modern Gold Rush, Can Memories Beat $913 an Ounce?
articles.snippet: As the price of gold rose sharply over the past year, thousands of Americans rushed to sell gold objects and heirlooms, some of which held deep emotional meaning.
articles.abstract: As the price of gold rose sharply over the past year, thousands of Americans rushed to sell gold objects and heirlooms, some of which held deep emotional meaning.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gold rushes should be simple money-making schemes.

articles.headline: Latest Hitch for Delphi, New Worry for G.M.
articles.snippet: A private equity group backed out of a deal to invest $2.55 billion in the auto-parts maker, dealing a blow to General Motors, which relies heavily on Delphi parts.
articles.abstract: A private equity group backed out of a deal to invest $2.55 billion in the auto-parts maker, dealing a blow to General Motors, which relies heavily on Delphi parts.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Delphi Corporation’s tortuous path out of bankruptcy went awry Friday when a private equity group backed out of a deal to invest $2.55 billion in the troubled auto-parts maker.

articles.headline: A Town Under Fire Becomes a Symbol for Israel
articles.snippet: Sderot, which has been pounded by Palestinian rockets, is on the front line of Israel’s battle for legitimacy and self-respect .
articles.abstract: Sderot, which has been pounded by Palestinian rockets, is on the front line of Israel’s battle for legitimacy and self-respect .
articles.lead_paragraph: SDEROT, Israel  This long neglected immigrant town a mile from Gaza, pounded by Palestinian rockets for the past seven years, is taking on a new identity, edging into the center of Zionist consciousness as a symbol of the nation’s unofficial motto: “Never Again.”

articles.headline: Leaders of Ruling Party Say Mugabe Will Fight On
articles.snippet: A decision that Zimbabwe’s president should participate in a possible run-off dampened speculation that he would step down.
articles.abstract: A decision that Zimbabwe’s president should participate in a possible run-off dampened speculation that he would step down.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  Dampening speculation that Zimbabwe’s strongman, President Robert Mugabe, would step down after 28 years in power, the senior leadership of the country’s ruling party decided Friday that he should participate in a runoff with the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, if neither won a majority in last week’s election.

articles.headline: While Alluring, Foreign Currencies Can Be Elusive
articles.snippet: While experts have different opinions about investing in foreign currencies, they all agree that such investments are not for the faint of heart.
articles.abstract: While experts have different opinions about investing in foreign currencies, they all agree that such investments are not for the faint of heart.
articles.lead_paragraph: Interest rates on savings accounts are falling. The dollar is weak. And the stock market is up one day and down the next. It is no wonder that even normally timid investors are hearing the siren song of foreign currencies.

articles.headline: In Massachusetts, Universal Coverage Strains Care
articles.snippet: An influx of newly insured patients is widening the gap between the supply of primary care physicians and the demand for their services.
articles.abstract: An influx of newly insured patients is widening the gap between the supply of primary care physicians and the demand for their services.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMHERST, Mass.  Once they discover that she is Dr. Kate, the supplicants line up to approach at dinner parties and ballet recitals. Surely, they suggest to Dr. Katherine J. Atkinson, a family physician here, she might find a way to move them up her lengthy waiting list for new patients.

articles.headline: Clintons Made $109 Million in Last 8 Years
articles.snippet: The Clintons released tax data showing a steep ascent in wealth since they left the White House.
articles.abstract: The Clintons released tax data showing a steep ascent in wealth since they left the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former President Bill Clinton released tax data Friday showing they earned $109 million over the last eight years, an ascent into the uppermost tier of American taxpayers that seemed unimaginable in 2001, when they left the White House with little money and facing millions in legal bills.

articles.headline: 80,000 Jobs Lost; Democrats Urge New Aid Package
articles.snippet: The speaker of the House said she would propose a second stimulus package amid job losses approaching those seen in 2001.
articles.abstract: The speaker of the House said she would propose a second stimulus package amid job losses approaching those seen in 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s employers eliminated tens of thousands of jobs for the third month in a row, the government reported Friday, and top Democrats immediately called for new measures to help suffering American workers.

articles.headline: Seeing the Sights of Industrial China: 2 Factories, 2 Futures
articles.snippet: China is caught between the reality of low-cost, tight-margin industries and a desire to advance in the production of higher-profit goods.
articles.abstract: China is caught between the reality of low-cost, tight-margin industries and a desire to advance in the production of higher-profit goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI

articles.headline: Microfinance’s Success Sets Off a Debate in Mexico
articles.snippet: As microlending becomes big business, a fractious debate is erupting in Mexico.
articles.abstract: As microlending becomes big business, a fractious debate is erupting in Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: VILLA DE VÁZQUEZ, Mexico  Carlos Danel and Carlos Labarthe turned a nonprofit that lent money to Mexico’s poor into one of the country’s most profitable banks.

articles.headline: Vocal on War, McCain Is Silent on Son’s Service
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain has staked his candidacy on the promise that U.S. troops can stabilize Iraq. What he almost never says is that one of them is his own son.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain has staked his candidacy on the promise that U.S. troops can stabilize Iraq. What he almost never says is that one of them is his own son.
articles.lead_paragraph: One evening last July, Senator John McCain of Arizona arrived at the New Hampshire home of Erin Flanagan for sandwiches, chocolate-chip cookies and heartfelt talk about Iraq. They had met at a presidential debate, when she asked the candidates what they would do to bring home American soldiers  soldiers like her brother, who had been killed in action a few months earlier.

articles.headline: A Brighter Spotlight, Yet the Pay Rises
articles.snippet: This was supposed to be the year of shareholder victory on the executive compensation front, but true links between pay and performance remain scarce.
articles.abstract: This was supposed to be the year of shareholder victory on the executive compensation front, but true links between pay and performance remain scarce.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASN’T 2008 supposed to be the year of shareholder victory on the executive compensation front?

articles.headline: A Road Not Taken by Lenders
articles.snippet: While borrowers may have misrepresented their incomes, lenders had the tools to identify these fibs before making the loans.
articles.abstract: While borrowers may have misrepresented their incomes, lenders had the tools to identify these fibs before making the loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WE’VE all heard a great deal in recent months about the greedy borrowers who caused the subprime mortgage calamity. Hordes of them duped unsuspecting lenders, don’t you know, by falsifying their incomes on loan documents. Now those loans are in default and the rapacious borrowers have moved on with their riches.

articles.headline: Tricky Task of Offering Aid to Homeowners
articles.snippet: Policy makers want any rescue effort to allow the government to recoup its costs if prices rebound.
articles.abstract: Policy makers want any rescue effort to allow the government to recoup its costs if prices rebound.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The task sounds nearly impossible: create a rescue plan for homeowners that will prevent a tidal wave of foreclosures, cost taxpayers as little as possible and avoid bailing out reckless lenders and greedy speculators.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Rival Resists Zimbabwe Runoff, Saying He Won
articles.snippet: According to news reports, President Robert Mugabe’s party, referring to “errors” in the tally, has asked for a recount in the election.
articles.abstract: According to news reports, President Robert Mugabe’s party, referring to “errors” in the tally, has asked for a recount in the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  The Zimbabwean opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai on Saturday insisted that he had won the presidential election outright and that no runoff vote would be needed. He also warned that the governing party was readying a campaign of violence against his supporters to hang on to power.

articles.headline: The Mortgage Bust Goes Global
articles.snippet: The consequences of millions of foreclosures across the U.S. are also being felt far overseas.
articles.abstract: The consequences of millions of foreclosures across the U.S. are also being felt far overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Basel, Switzerland

articles.headline: Amazon Accelerates Its Move to Digital
articles.snippet: With the No. 1 source of music sales now an online downloading service, Amazon.com looks at the development of its digital offerings with a sense of urgency.
articles.abstract: With the No. 1 source of music sales now an online downloading service, Amazon.com looks at the development of its digital offerings with a sense of urgency.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  Over the last 14 years, Amazon.com has mastered the art of getting physical copies of books, music and movies to customers through the mail. Now it is trying to add to its repertoire in a hurry.

articles.headline: Vanity Fair and the Private Eye
articles.snippet: Vanity Fair has ended up mired in the intrigue of the trial of Anthony Pellicano, the private investigator charged with wiretapping and racketeering.
articles.abstract: Vanity Fair has ended up mired in the intrigue of the trial of Anthony Pellicano, the private investigator charged with wiretapping and racketeering.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Anthony Pellicano trial, with its list of boldface names and recordings of wiseguy phone huddles played in open court, would seem to be a dream come true for Vanity Fair, a magazine that has a soft spot for Hollywood power and its discontents.

articles.headline: U.S. and Iraqis Battle Militias to End Attacks
articles.snippet: At least three U.S. soldiers were killed and 31 wounded and at least 20 Iraqis were killed in a failed operation to stop militia attacks on Baghdad’s Green Zone.
articles.abstract: At least three U.S. soldiers were killed and 31 wounded and at least 20 Iraqis were killed in a failed operation to stop militia attacks on Baghdad’s Green Zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Sharp fighting broke out in the Sadr City district of Baghdad on Sunday as American and Iraqi troops sought to control neighborhoods used by Shiite militias to fire rockets and mortars into the nearby Green Zone.
articles.byline: By Erica Goode and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Medicare Finds How Hard It Is to Save Money
articles.snippet: An ambitious experiment to save Medicare dollars is proving how difficult it can be to change the program.
articles.abstract: An ambitious experiment to save Medicare dollars is proving how difficult it can be to change the program.
articles.lead_paragraph: An ambitious three-year experiment to see whether the Medicare system could prevent expensive hospital visits for people with chronic conditions like congestive heart failure and diabetes has suggested that such an approach may cost more than it saves.

articles.headline: Top Clinton Aide Leaving His Post Under Pressure
articles.snippet: Mark Penn stepped down as Hillary Rodham Clinton’s chief strategist after his business arrangements again clashed with her campaign positions.
articles.abstract: Mark Penn stepped down as Hillary Rodham Clinton’s chief strategist after his business arrangements again clashed with her campaign positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE  Mark Penn, the pollster who has advised Bill and Hillary Clinton since 1996, stepped down under pressure on Sunday as the chief political strategist for Mrs. Clinton’s struggling presidential campaign after his private business arrangements again clashed with her campaign positions.

articles.headline: Is Cuisine Still Italian Even if the Chef Isn’t?
articles.snippet: Italy’s restaurants are now a snapshot of the country’s recent immigrant experience, raising the question: Does the cuisine become less Italian if anyone can prepare it?
articles.abstract: Italy’s restaurants are now a snapshot of the country’s recent immigrant experience, raising the question: Does the cuisine become less Italian if anyone can prepare it?
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Last month, Gambero Rosso, the prestigious reviewer of restaurants and wine, sought out Rome’s best carbonara, a dish of pasta, eggs, pecorino cheese and guanciale (cured pig cheek; for the aficionados, pancetta is not done) that defines tradition here.

articles.headline: Rifts in Family and Companies Hang Over Redstone's Legacy
articles.snippet: Sumner M. Redstone, the media mogul, has left a trail of tattered relationships with family members and executives, leaving open the question of who will succeed him.
articles.abstract: Sumner M. Redstone, the media mogul, has left a trail of tattered relationships with family members and executives, leaving open the question of who will succeed him.
articles.lead_paragraph: In mid-March, the media mogul Sumner M. Redstone was in Palm Beach, Fla., for a Wall Street firm’s annual media conference when he was asked about his legacy.

articles.headline: 2 Outcomes When Foreigners Buy Factories
articles.snippet: Two cities offer competing narratives for a nation uneasy about being on the selling end of the global economy.
articles.abstract: Two cities offer competing narratives for a nation uneasy about being on the selling end of the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLAND, Mich.  Four years ago, a low-slung factory on the fringes of town here was stagnating and shedding workers. Then Siemens, the German industrial giant, bought the plant and folded it into a global enterprise. Today, the factory is shipping wastewater treatment equipment to Asia and the Middle East and employing twice as many workers.

articles.headline: Sam Zell: A Tough Guy in a Mean Business
articles.snippet: Sam Zell, the owner of the Tribune Company, faces difficult choices ahead, as his company struggles under $12.8 billion in debt and looks at a very real risk of credit default.
articles.abstract: Sam Zell, the owner of the Tribune Company, faces difficult choices ahead, as his company struggles under $12.8 billion in debt and looks at a very real risk of credit default.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since taking control of the Tribune Company in December, Sam Zell has drawn a lot of attention in journalism circles for speeches laced with profanity, political incorrectness, insults and self-deprecating humor.
